Vector.short_description: A quantity that has both magnitude and direction, often used in mathematics, physics, and computer graphics.

Magnitude.short_description: The size or amount of a quantity, often a component of a vector.

Direction.short_description: The orientation or path along which something moves or lies, often a component of a vector.

Displacement.short_description: The change in position of an object, often represented as a vector.

Velocity.short_description: The speed of something in a given direction, often represented as a vector.

Acceleration.short_description: The rate of change of velocity of an object, often represented as a vector.

Force.short_description: An interaction that, when unopposed, will change the motion of an object, often represented as a vector.

Field.short_description: A region of space around a body or object in which a force is exerted, often involving vectors.

Component.short_description: One of the parts that make up a whole, often referring to the individual parts of a vector.

Resolution.short_description: The ability to distinguish between two closely spaced objects, often referring to the clarity of vector graphics.

Path.short_description: The route or course taken in getting from one point to another, often described by a vector.

Trajectory.short_description: The path that a moving object follows through space, often described by a vector.

Gradient.short_description: A rate or vector of change in a scalar field, often involving vectors.

Normal.short_description: A vector that is perpendicular to a surface or object, often used in physics and computer graphics.

Tangent.short_description: A vector that touches a curve or surface at a single point without crossing it, often used in mathematics and physics.

Span.short_description: The set of all possible linear combinations of a given set of vectors, often used in linear algebra.

Norm.short_description: A function that assigns a strictly positive length or size to all vectors in a vector space, except for the zero vector.

Orthogonality.short_description: The state of being perpendicular, often referring to vectors that are orthogonal to each other.

Linear Independence.short_description: The property of a set of vectors where no vector in the set can be written as a linear combination of the others.

Eigenvector.short_description: A special vector associated with a linear system of equations that, when multiplied by a matrix, results in a scalar multiple of itself.

Eigenvalue.short_description: A scalar associated with a given linear transformation of a vector space and a corresponding eigenvector.
